content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Everyone loves wordle!

Very nice addition to the Optimization puzzles.
Excellent responses to all the feedback.
I'm ready to approve, but I think there is 1 more change.

It's important that the Validators are random, as they are.
But I think the Test Cases should not be random.
Here's why. Imagine I'm writing my program (with some bugs).
I need to modify my program, then re-run it against the same secret word. If the secret word for the Test Case changes every time, it's much more difficult to debug my program. Once my program is bug-free, I want to Submit and have it scored against randomly generated words in the Validators.

Looking at Bulls & Cows 2, that is how it was done.
This looks really good!
You did a really good job of coding this!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: changes suggestions were taken into account, ready to be published

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The man did the work.

Updated the game with several changes based on feedback received throughout the review process, including:

- Improved the statement by making it clearer and fixing grammar mistakes

- Updated the test cases to be dynamic rather than having a fixed word for each test case

- Handled the presence of special characters in the user's guess to prevent the game crashes

- Limited the maximum number of turns to 26

- Added starting screen and ending screen

- Added player avatar

- Updated game summaries for turn info, success, and failure scenarios

I believe the changes have improved the overall experience of the game and now it's ready for approval.

I think you are almost there. But ...

Wording for the game summary in case of success should be "Congratulations! You guessed the word". You should also output a message in case of failure to guess the word. 
An ending screen would be handy (reuse your WORDLE starting screen).
great work!

As this is an optim, you should add more validators. I think you can go up to 4 x 12.
A critical question: are your validators randomly generated or harcoded ? In the latter case, people will be able to hardcode the solutions and your optim will become pointless. I suggest that you look at https://www.codingame.com/multiplayer/optimization/bulls-and-cows-2

Many typos and language fixes are needed
* addaptation -> adaptation
* slightly modification -> slight modifications
* At the start of the game player -> At the start of the game, the player
* Each turn player -> At each turn, the player
* After each guess player will know the states of the letters -> After each guess, the player will know the state of each letter
* The word player will guess not necessarily be a real word -> The word the player will have to guess is not necessarily a real word
* You guess correct before the time is out -> You guess the word in less than 27 turns
* You use more than 26 guess -> You use more than 26 guesses
* wordLength amount of -> wordLength   (repeated twice)

You did not specify how much time is allocated for one turn

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Its good
Good idea

This is AMAZING! I loved Wordle and making it a game sounds like a great idea.

I have some questions before moving on:
- Can you share just the source code of the game (not the solution words)? You mentioned v1 was multiplayer - do you have a link with previous feedback?
- I know wordle is optimized based on letter occurrence probability in source thesaurus (e.g. see https://jonathanolson.net/wordle-solver/ ). You mentioned "word is not necessarily real" - is it random?
- If words are random (or secret), could a "perfect" solution make top of leaderboard decided by RNG? I'm not sure how can this be fixed, but I'm giving it a thought.

Thanks for creating this game. I imagine you prefer making this optimization above a puzzle, so I'll think how can it work in case the random part breaks the challenge.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: good job

I still have a question, what happens if (like in the instructions), player guessed ABBEY but the word we are looking for has a "B" in the 2nd position?
B in 2nd position will have a status "3", but should "B" in 3rd position have status 1 or 2?
thanks in advance!!

Really like the idea! :-)
Thanks Tanvir for the contribution. 

Instructions are clear to me. 

Thanks for explaining how the game works for double letters.

In test cases, are the one mentioned (Validator) the one used as validators when you submit ? 

If that's so, I guess you could find the words by tghe IDE and then submit your code with only these words to cheat and improve your rank... 

When can you have a 0 state ? I don't understand how it might be possible.
niceee
Interesting

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

I think this game would be more interesting if the number of trials limit was smaller. At the moment it is enough to test all the letters to get the solution. (Even if I imagine that the ranking system is an implicit limit)
[EDIT] Never mind, I massively misunderstood how the game works.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

"Leaderboard is ascended by the total guesses among all the test cases." Do you really mean "test cases", or do you actually mean "validators"?

Also, just to confirm, do the words in the validators always stay the same, or are they randomised every time a code is submitted?

Thanks.

In the Constraints section, do you mean wordLength instead of wordCount?

In the Goal section, please state how a player is scored (specify the criteria) for the purpose of leaderboard ranking. Examples from other optimisation games:

CGFunge Prime: "This is an optimization problem, your program should use as few execution steps as possible to find the correct answer."

Bulls and Cows 2: "Score board is ascended by the total count of actions among all the test cases."

Bender - Episode 4: "The solution will be scored by the length of the string, the shorter the better."

Also please make sure the ranking works properly. (There was one incident where a contribution initially got the scoring work in the opposite order to that intended...)

Thanks.

I don't know if it was your intention, but this puzzle is much harder with the edited rule of all same letters being state 2 if there's only one letter present in the word. For example,
given the word LEMON, if 2 L's were guessed, and neither were in the correct position, both would be state 2. In the actual game the first would be state 2 and the second state 1, indicating only one of the letter L's was needed.

This is v2 of the game, updated based on your feedback for the v1 (https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/300786b69fbadfb92cea9bfc0a46118e014b3).
Changelog:
  - Converted from Multiplayer to Optimization
  - Variety in the word length
  - No limited word set
  - Improved statement

Hope you like the game and share your valuable feedback.

Yeah, this is intentional to give the game some depth and also to make the rules simpler to understand. You can see the actual rules for the same letters from https://nerdschalk.com/wordle-same-letter-twice-rules-explained-how-does-it-work/
which is a bit complicated

Yes, I wanted to mean word length in the Constraints section. I have fixed that and updated the goal to include the ranking criteria. I have also double-checked the configuration to make sure that the leaderboard orders by the count of guesses in ascending order. 
Thanks for your feedback!

I'm not sure if there is a way to control whether the total is calculated from the validators only or from both validators and test cases. My guess is that it calculates from only the validators by default. Can you give me a clue if it's possible to control how I want to calculate the total? Or, should I just mention validators instead of test cases?

And the validators remain the same for every submission.
[EDIT] Never mind, I massively misunderstood how the game works.
At the moment it has eight test cases having unique and duplicate letters in words to let the player validate their code before submitting, did you mean reducing the number of these test cases?

Really appreciate your feedback. Yes, the validators are used to validate the submissions. Once a contribution has been approved, the validators' test cases are usually not visible to users. I don't know if there is a way to see the validator test cases unless someone copies the test cases while the contribution is being reviewed for approval.

The state of a letter can only be 0 in the first round because the user does not have a previous guess in the first round to maintain consistency between input and output flow.

To answer your question, I believe that in the first example, "ORBIT" is the word and the player has guessed "ABBEY."
 The third "B" in "ABBEY" matches with the third "B" in "ORBIT" so has a state of 3.
 While the second "B" in "ABBEY" doesn't match with the 2nd letter in "ORBIT" and "B" is present in "ORBIT" so it gets a state of 2.

Therefore, in the case you described, the third "B" if it doesn't match the third letter of the word you looking for would have a state of 2.
Hope it makes sense now.

Thank you for your initial approval of my contribution. I have made some improvements to the game, including correcting typos and language errors, adding additional test cases, and making the test cases dynamic rather than having a fixed word for each test case. Would you mind taking a look again and considering these updates? 
Thank you for your time and consideration.

Thank you for your interest and feedback. I am glad you love the idea of making Wordle a programming puzzle. 
I apologize for taking so long to respond. In the meantime, I have made some updates to the game, including fixing typos and language errors, adding extra test cases, and making the test cases dynamic instead of having a fixed word for each test case.

In response to your questions:
 - I'd be happy to share the source code of the game. Here is the link https://github.com/tanvir362/wordle-optimization
Regarding v1, it was a multiplayer version. You can find previous feedback here https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/300786b69fbadfb92cea9bfc0a46118e014b3
 - The word to be guessed is not necessarily random, but players are allowed to make some random guesses to have some clues. 
 - I am not sure if there is still an issue with this aspect. If there is, would you elaborate on it a bit more?
Thank you for your approval of my contribution. I have made some improvements to the game afterward. Would you mind taking a look again and considering these updates?
I truly appreciate your diligence in identifying those typos and errors. I have corrected them and added some extra test cases.

Can you elaborate what you mean by "hardcoded"? Does it refer to having a fixed or unchanging value for a test case? The puzzle you mentioned seems to have a similar approach, where the secret remains constant for each test case.

Thanks for taking the time to review once again and suggesting the necessary changes. I believe these changes have improved the overall quality of the contribution.

Updated with the following changes:
- Updated game summary of turn info
- Updated game summary on success
- Added game summary on failure
- Handle special characters in guess
- Added end screen
Thanks for reapproval
Thanks for your approval
Thanks for your feedback. I understand the pain point you described for debugging. I'm currently working on it and will update as soon as possible.

Updated! 
Now the test cases are static along with the randomized validators. 

Again thanks for your feedback

I should have written "predefined" or "static". Yes, I mean having a fixed value for a test case. For each test case, Bulls and Cows generates a new random secret. You can read the contribution history for more details.
I've updated the test cases. Now the word selected for each test case will be randomly picked from a list of words with the same length, rather than repeating the same word every time.

I have made further updates to the game, including fixing punctuation and article mistakes, clarifying the defeat conditions, improving the constraints section, etc.

I believe the contribution is now in a good state to be approved, would you please take a look once again and share your thoughts?

It doesn't look very random to me... I've just run all the validators in the contribution view, and here are the repeated words:

(appears 3 times)
STOOR
NOZZLE
WAFTURE
SECURITY

(appears 2 times)
SCAUP
ELECT
TROPHY
TICKET
APEAK
JUMBUCK
DACKERED
SPICULUM

Would you please take a look and see if anything can be done about the non-randomness?

P.S. There's a message on the forum on this puzzle too, in case you do not know yet.

Thanks.

I didn't notice the forum message, thanks for commenting here.

Previously, there was a fixed mapping between validators and words. For instance, validator1 -> word1, validator2 -> word2, validator3 -> word2, and so on, up to validatorN -> wordN. Each validator could only point to a single specific word. 
This has now changed, validators are no longer restricted to pointing to their original assigned word. They can now point to any random word that has the same length as their original assigned word. This means that some words may appear more than once, but there is no guarantee that any particular word will appear more than once.

Adding more words could potentially improve the randomness, but it cannot guarantee that no word will appear more than once. 
I'm not sure how critical it is to avoid a word from appearing more than once to ensure randomness in this particular context. 
I would appreciate your input on this matter.

I think a word or two being repeated once is acceptable, given that you have no control over randomness. But having a dozen of words repeated two or three times is a bit too much. It's just like ordinary puzzles having duplicated validators.

Given that there are 50 validators in total, would it be possible to allocate e.g. 50 words to each validator, making it a total of 2500 different words? That will ensure that no two validators test the same word. During the allocation, you can at the same time ensure that some validators test words with unique letters only, while other validators test words with 2 or more repeated letters.

Thanks.

Assigning separate word sets for each validator to prevent duplicate validators seems like a good idea. As for the amount 2500 seems a bit tricky for now since I collect words manually from various sources to avoid bias toward any particular source. 
I'll come up with something around it, As soon as I get some time.

Thanks
Sounds good to me, thanks :)

Tanvir, FYI:
https://forum.codingame.com/t/community-puzzle-wordle/199788/6

I would rather come up with a solution that generates a completely random word (as in rand%26 for each letter) when starting the test. The only exception to this rule would be some public test cases that are used to debug your algorithm.
An alternative solution would be to have a very large dictionary (provided that it fits within CG constraints)
In retrospect, a small dictionary (50 to 100 words) is only needed to defeat hardcoding.

The problem is that currently we have 50 validators. And that means having 50 words is ENOUGH for hardcoding :D

Also, as mentioned by some players, "fully random would be less interesting" and I agree with that.

Thanks for your response.
About p.3: I'll take some time to solve this properly, in case I got something wrong.

I think I misunderstood the IDE interface for contributions. 
I guess the validators test cases won't be available while doing the challenge for "normal" players. ;-)  

Thanks for explaining the 0 state.
I meant that 30 guesses for every test cases is too much since the player can just try the whole alphabet with words like 'AAAAA', 'BBBBB' etc. I suggest to reduce this number of guesses.
I updated the maximum guess limit and set it to 26, so the brute force solutions got accepted too. But the solutions need to be optimized to have a better rank in the leaderboard.
What have you misunderstood? Is there anything I can do to help ensure this doesn't happen again with anyone else?

Thank you for your reply.

I am not sure. Better ask somebody who has the experience and knowledge :wink: I am simply confused by the words "all the test cases"; that's why I asked.

Since our last conversation, I have made some improvements to the game, including correcting typos and language errors, adding additional test cases, and making the test cases dynamic rather than having a fixed word for each test case. 
Would you mind taking a look again and considering these updates?

Thank you for inviting me for a re-review! :)

Goal section
* (If my understanding is correct...) Suggest to add "(for the first turn only)" after "State 0 means unknown."

* Please change "as following" to "as follows".

* Please change "the both" to "both the" (2 times).

* Please change "ABBEY." to "ABBEY," (3 times).

* Defeat conditions - point 2: Could "invalid action" be replaced by something more precise? e.g. "invalid guess"? And what is an invalid guess? A guess which is too short or too long?

* Can the Note section be deleted? Reasons: Better details have been provided in Input and Output sections, and "contextual data" and "desired instructions" are ambiguous.

Constraints section
* FirstTurnMaxTime, TurnMaxTime and MaxTurns are not defined anywhere. Suggest to use plain words instead:
• Response time for first turn
• Response time for second and subsequent turns
• Maximum number of turns

Thanks.

Thank you for taking the time to review the contribution once again and provide valuable feedback. 

I have made the suggested updates including fixing punctuation and article mistakes, removing the note section, and updating the defeat conditions and constraints section.

I believe the contribution is now in a good state to be approved. If you feel the same way, would you please consider approving?

Again, Thank you for your time and support.

One more fix:
* Defeat conditions - point 2: Please change "A guess" to "You make a guess". Thanks.

I've reviewed the statement but I haven't written a code to test the puzzle, so it doesn't feel appropriate for me to approve it. It looks like a good puzzle, though, so I hope it'll get approved by those who have tried it!

Thank you for your reviews, I will fix the error as well. I understand that you haven't written code to test the puzzle, so I respect your decision not to approve it. I hope someone who has tried it will find it interesting and approve. 
Thank you again for your support.
Do "fewest guesses" refer to summing up the number of guesses for all validators? If so, better specify that ;)

Yeah, I'll update :)
Thanks
